thread.title: Red Wings rookie Dylan Larkin, 19, gets assist, goal in first game
thread.title_full: Red Wings rookie Dylan Larkin, 19, gets assist, goal in first game

author: freep.com
title: Red Wings rookie Dylan Larkin, 19, gets assist, goal in first game
text:
MORE It was just one game, but what a game it was for Dylan Larkin.
In his NHL debut, Larkin, the 19-year-old Waterford native drafted 15th overall by the Detroit Red Wings in 2014, scored a goal and an assist in a 4-0 win over the Toronto Maple Leafs .
"It's a special night for me and I'm going to enjoy it a little bit and then get ready for Carolina," said Larkin. The Wings visit the Hurricanes on Saturday.
Larkin, who starred at Michigan as a freshman last season, didn't appear to look out of place on a line with Justin Abdelkader (three goals) and Henrik Zetterberg (three assists).
Larkin admitted to having some pre-game jitters, especially when it came to the player introductions.
"You're just trying to focus not to fall," Larkin said. "First shift, I tied my skates too tight. My toes, weren't really feeling them. After that I kind of settled in and felt pretty comfortable."
About 30 members of Larkin's family, including his parents, Kevin and Sydney Denise, watched their son finish plus-3 in 13:42 on Friday night at Joe Louis Arena in the Wings' season opener.
The Wings resisted the urge to have Larkin start out playing for the Grand Rapids Griffins of the American Hockey League.
"He played well," said Wings general manager Ken Holland. "He's playing with two good players in Abby and Z. For one night they were very, very good. Obviously, Dylan did lots of good things.
"He didn't make the team because he played good in preseason. The preseason for me was the final evaluation test that he passed. He was a Big Ten rookie of the year. ... played in the world juniors, then the world championships."
New Wings head coach Jeff Blashill wanted Larkin in the lineup and Holland said he did too, provided that Larkin received top nine minutes.
The decision to play Larkin on the top line paid off at 8:20 into the first period when he assisted on Abdelkader's second goal of the first period.
Larkin, after battling with the puck against Leafs defenseman Jake Gardiner, got a shot off. Then he got the puck back and fed Abdelkader to put the Wings ahead, 2-0.
"I had the puck for a quick second," Larkin said. "I thought it was Z in front of the net. But it was Abby. I saw his backhand there and just threw it there and he did the rest. It was a great play by him."
Larkin scored 20 seconds into the second period to give the Wings a three-goal cushion. He took a pass from Henrik Zetterberg and picked the top corner to beat Jonathan Bernier.
"Had a lot of speed and just ripped it," Larkin said. "I think (Bernier) was cheating a little bit. I don't know, off his angle but it worked out pretty well."
According to team statistician Greg Innis, Larkin became the first teenager to start a season opener for the Wings since Mike Sillinger played in a 3-3 tie at the New Jersey Devils on Oct. 4, 1990.
Abdelkader said he was a little concerned for Larkin about all the hype surrounding his first NHL game.
"He's such a good player, he proved every bit as good," Abdelkader said. "He's a great player. For a teenager to make the opening day roster, it's out of the norm."
It wasn't the first time the Larkin family had enjoyed a win by the Red Wings over the Leafs.
Kevin Larkin, Dylan's father, told the Free Press earlier in the day that one of the family traditions was putting tickets each season for a Leafs-Wings game in the Christmas stockings of the Larkin boys.
"We all attended this game for the past 10 years," Kevin said. "So it's very cool that he's playing in it now."
What will go in Dylan Larkin's stocking this year?
"What's he putting in my stocking?," Kevin Larkin replied, with a laugh.
Kevin Larkin said his mother and sister made the trip from Toronto. Other relatives traveled from Milwaukee, Evansville, Ind. and Georgetown, Ky.
Dylan's older brother, Colin, who plays hockey at Division III UMass-Boston, flew in on Thursday for the game.
"It meant a lot for them to come in and support me," Dylan said. "My mom was telling me they haven't had this much family together since their wedding. It's a big deal and I'm glad it worked out for everybody coming up."
Contact George Sipple: gsipple@freepress.com. @georgesipple . Check out our new Red Wings Xtra app on Apple and Android !
DETROIT FREE PRESS
